Yes, it's a lot of money, but BAC has already shown that it can weather the storm, and I don't see any reason to think it couldn't weather this as well. Yes, it's hard on investors, but for those who have a very long outlook, this simply continues the excellent opportunity to accumulate stock for an excellent company that will pay off in the long run. Those who think being long means holding the stock overnight need to get a life and learn what being long really means.

Topic.Title: Potential $6 billion fine

Message.Msg: One other thing to keep in mind, that while FHFA is "seeking" $6 billion from BAC, that's not saying they are anywhere near close to agreement. My thinking is any final settlement will be much less, particularly considering all the settlements BAC already has with Fannie and Freddie. Everyone forgets that JPM has gotten off light on this whole mortgage mess up until now, while BAC and C have both hit multiple times. My thought is that BAC will point that out very forcefully.

Message.Title: BAC: Moving towards a market-leading position
Message.Msg: Bank of America (BAC) has a market-leading position in U.S. leveraged finance, but not so in Europe, and senior bankers say the bank is set to commit more capital and staff to change that. It's the only lender to have had a hand in the three largest European M&A deals this year - Virgin Media, DE Masters Blenders, and Ista - and the bank has risen from 13th in the ranking to 4th so far in 2013.

Topic.Title: Potential $6 billion fine

Message.Msg: ROTFLMAO you'd make a great historian except for having tunnel vision and the lazy neocon trait of ignoring a mountain of contrary evidence looking for one cherry to support your indefensible position. Here are a few other things on that record of mine you must have overlooked or forgotten. I came to this board in early 2011 as a PO'd multiple account holder, not a shareholder, and have never traded a single share of this corporate coprolite, long OR short. I came here with a warning that this dog was in grave need of serious veterinary attention (at the time BAC was trading a little north of $14 a share - just about where it is today, more than 2 1/2 years later. ROTFLMAO talk about dead money!), but I stayed for the entertainment you and other great performers like stevens1958 and tonka_et_al provide, and as a break from my more serious [demented] writing. I DID say that BAC at $6 was a bust, but I said it TWICE....once before it dropped below $5, and again as it was being hauled from its grave by what turned out to be QE ad infinitum ad nauseam and Warren's deep pockets and political connections. Here's another post of mine (April 19, 2011) you must have overlooked during your extensive historical research: "About 2 months ago I posted a warning on this board that B of A was likely to run into some serious headwinds, particularly in the area of public opinion, and as an example of what to expect mentioned this fledgling protest group, US Uncut. I predicted that their message about large tax-avoiding corporations like BAC and GE ("I pay, we pay, why doesn't B of A?") was likely to resonate with the public, and that the rosy forecasts of $18 to $22 per share by some on this board seemed out of touch with reality, at least the reality out there on the streets that aren't named 'Wall'". Hmm: share price a bit above $14; the herd bleating about $18-22 just around the corner; ROTFLMAO are ya ready for a little lesson about history repeating itself, brent?
